article.title: Strongly order continuous operators on Riesz spaces

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following statements is **NOT** true about strongly order continuous (so-continuous) operators?
choices: An operator T: E → F between two Riesz spaces is so-continuous if xₐ  →  0 in E implies Txₐ  →  0 in F.
Every so-continuous operator is order continuous.
The identity operator I: c₀ → c₀ (where c₀ is the space of real-valued sequences converging to 0) is an example of an so-continuous operator.
The collection of all so-continuous operators of L<sub>b</sub>(E, F) is denoted by L<sub>so</sub>(E, F).

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following is equivalent to an order bounded linear functional *f* on a Riesz space E being so-continuous?
What is the definition of an order closed ideal in a Riesz space?
choices: A subset A where if (xₐ) ⊂ A and xₐ  →  x, then x ∈ A.
A subset A that is closed under addition and scalar multiplication.
A subset A that contains the supremum of every one of its subsets.
A subset A that contains the absolute value of each of its elements.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main result presented in Theorem 2 of the text?
choices: If E is a Riesz space, then L<sub>so</sub>(E, R) and L<sub>soo</sub>(E, R) are both ideals of E~.
If E is a Riesz space, then L<sub>so</sub>(E, R) and L<sub>soo</sub>(E, R) are both bands of E~.
If E is a Riesz space, then the modulus of a so-continuous operator on E is also so-continuous.
If E is a finite-dimensional Riesz space, then L<sub>so</sub>(E, F) = L<sub>n</sub>(E, F) and L<sub>soo</sub>(E, F) = L<sub>c</sub>(E, F).
